title: Purdue's Sackler Family Owners Worth $11 Billion, Documents Show
summary: The disclosures show wealth built up by Purdue's family owners, who have offered to pay $4.28 billion in a proposed bankruptcy deal. Members of the Sackler family who own bankrupt OxyContin-maker Purdue Pharma LP are worth approximately $11 billion, documents released Tuesday by a congressional committee show.

title: Netflix Subscriber Growth Slows as Economies Reopen
summary: Subscriptions at streaming giant surged last year, but consumers are now looking to get out. Netflix Inc. said subscriber growth for the first quarter was weaker than expected, a potential warning sign for the company as consumers in many countries start to emerge from pandemic-related lockdowns and as streaming competition increases.

title: Foxconn Shrinks Plans for Wisconsin Plant
summary: Electronics maker signs new deal with state to invest up to $672 million, instead of up to $10 billion. Foxconn is scaling back plans for a liquid-crystal-display plant in Wisconsin, saying it expects to invest a fraction of the $10 billion promised nearly four years ago, according to a new contract with the state.

title: Boeing CFO Guided Aircraft Maker Through 737 MAX Crisis
summary: In an unexpected move, Greg Smith is set to retire in July. Boeing Co. 's finance chief Greg Smith served as a steady hand during the aircraft manufacturer's recent years of tumult from the grounding of the 737 MAX to the coronavirus pandemic. Finding a successor after his unexpected departure might be tough, people close to the company and analysts said.

title: Senate Confirms Lisa Monaco as Deputy Attorney General
summary: Experienced national-security official takes Justice Department's No. 2 job with focus on Jan. 6 riot probe, domestic and foreign threats. WASHINGTON-The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Lisa Monaco to be deputy attorney general, putting a seasoned national-security official in charge of the Justice Department's day-to-day operations as it confronts a rise in domestic extremism and threats from abroad.

title: Canadian National Makes $30 Billion Topping Bid for Kansas City Southern
summary: Offer represents 21% premium to agreement with Canadian Pacific reached last month. Canadian National Railway Co. made a roughly $30 billion bid for Kansas City Southern , kicking off a bidding war for a railroad operator that has already agreed to a sale to another Canadian rival.

title: Amazon Does Haircuts Now
summary: The e-commerce giant said its first salon will be a place to collaborate with the professional beauty industry and test new technologies. Amazon. com Inc. opened its first hair salon Tuesday. Located in London's Spitalfields shopping district, Amazon Salon offers hairdressing services dressed up with technology, including augmented-reality hair consultations.

title: Biden to Back Temporary Extension of Larger Child Tax Credit
summary: Some Democratic lawmakers have pressed for a permanent change to the payments. WASHINGTON-President Biden told a group of lawmakers that he intends to propose a temporary extension of an enhanced child tax credit, rebuffing requests from some Democrats who favor making the new benefit permanent.

title: Derek Chauvin's Trial Was an Experiment in Pandemic Justice
summary: The proceeding to determine guilt in George Floyd's death featured masked attorneys, plexiglass and white-noise machines. MINNEAPOLIS-As the Derek Chauvin trial unfolded over the past several weeks, it was the first time most people around the country got a glimpse into the strange new reality of a jury trial during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: New York City Mayor Unveils Plans to Curb Gun Crimes
summary: Community investment, redeployment of police part of plan to combat surge of gun violence in the city. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday unveiled new initiatives aimed at reducing an uptick in gun violence that has plagued the city over the past year.

title: The Era of Easy Money
summary: Enjoy it while it lasts.. The Federal Reserve has created more than $3.5 trillion since the start of the Covid panic and all those dollars have to go somewhere. Lately they seem to be going everywhere. Great companies, decent companies, weak companies with entertaining Internet memes and even businesses created as jokes are now getting funded.

title: J&J Vaccine Benefits Outweigh Risks, EU Agency Says, as U.S. Cases Rise
summary: U.S. tally of blood-clot cases linked to the vaccine rises to nine. Europe's health agency said a warning should be added to the product information of the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine that unusual blood clots are a very rare possible side effect, but said the benefits of taking the shot outweigh the risks.

title: Is AT&T a Train Wreck?
summary: The company's epic adventure in reinvention reaches a moment of truth.. There's nothing like reaching out to a Wall Street analyst whom I know only by reputation and hearing that he was just thinking of me too. Apparently I need to write something to encourage AT&T 's board to get the company off its suicide mission.

title: The $1 Trillion Tax Evasion Opportunity
summary: A little spending on the IRS could yield a lot of revenue that's going uncollected.. Internal Revenue Service Commissioner Charles Rettig told the Senate Finance Committee last week that the annual gap between taxes owed and taxes paid could be as much as $1 trillion. The so-called tax gap has doubled over the past decade, as IRS resources shrank. The number of IRS employees has declined by 33,000, with more than half of the decrease coming in the hard-pressed enforcement division. As a result, Mr. Rettig says, the IRS is "outgunned."

title: Apple's iPad and Mac Moment Should Linger
summary: Tablet and PC sales got a strong boost from the Covid-19 pandemic. Changed work habits should keep demand elevated.. Apple Inc.'s new iPad and iMac might seem a bit late to the game, but there is good reason to think they will still find their mark.

title: A Shipping Crisis Waiting to Happen
summary: Enormous container vessels move goods efficiently-but a lot could go wrong.. When the Ever Given container ship got stuck in the Suez Canal, it showed the vulnerability of the global shipping system, which carries products around the world at surprisingly low cost. But there's an even more worrisome problem: Ships are getting too big.

title: 'Blood and Treasure' Review: A Boone for the Frontier
summary: Daniel Boone despised his reputation as an Indian ﬁghter. He was vastly more proud of his ability to endure the burdens of the huntsman's life.. Bob Drury and Tom Clavin together have given us a half-dozen elegantly written narratives of exhilarating episodes in American history, ranging from events in the Indian Wars of the American West to the Korean War. Among their outstanding co-authored works are "The Last Stand of Fox Company: A True Story of U. S. Marines in Combat" (2009) and "The Heart of Everything That Is: The Untold Story of Red Cloud" (2013).

title: Democrats Are Fooling Themselves on Immigration
summary: Voters didn't always like Trump's tone, but they broadly supported his strategy at the border.. Out to lunch. That might be the kindest way to describe Joe Biden and Democrats these days on immigration. If they think they have a voter mandate to reverse restrictions advanced by the previous administration, even with the southern border effectively under siege, they're kidding themselves.

title: Even in Cricket, No Rest From the Woke
summary: The venerable term 'batsman' has been banished from an ESPN website.. Many culture wars start as skirmishes in obscure corners of human interaction, sparked by a remark in a lecture at a small university or by an aperçu at a meeting of local officials. Yet the most passionate cultural tussles seem to begin in matters related to sports-as has just happened with cricket, a team game so venerable that even Oliver Cromwell refrained from prohibiting its play in the Puritan years when he governed England. (Cromwell banned other sports, as well as the theater, but halted cricket only on the sabbath.)

summary: New products heighten competition with Spotify, other rivals that have criticized how tech giant wields its market power. summary: A modest subject belies the magic of Japan Society's current show.. New York

title: 'Generation Hustle' Review: True Grift
summary: An HBO Max documentary reels viewers in with the stories of brazen fraudsters who hoodwinked their victims in pursuit of fame and fortune.. Since the con-artistry extravaganza "Generation Hustle" makes its debut on Thursday, and the Academy Awards are on Sunday, one's thoughts might turn to "The Sting" of 1973. In that Best Picture winner, the point is made that the greatest flimflams of all are the ones in which the victims never even realize they've been snookered. Such was not the case with the instances of deception and fraud recounted in "Generation Hustle," of course, or there would be no show. But what kind of ingenious minds could pull off such near-masterpieces of deception and be satisfied that no one would ever know?

title: The U.S. Sports Origins of Europe's Soccer Super League
summary: Four of the 12 rebel clubs are owned by Americans. But the influence of stateside sports models has been around much longer.. For as long as the English Premier League has existed, its most powerful owners have watched the NFL. The founders, self-made British businessmen, had seen it firsthand by traveling to the U.S. and loved it all: the glitz, the lavish television contracts, the lionized dynasties. By the time they founded the Premier League in 1992, they had a clear picture of how to make money from modern sports.

title: New York MTA's Plan to Upgrade Transit Threatened by Pandemic
summary: Lost revenue and increased borrowing triggered by the pandemic put capital spending at risk, state comptroller says. The New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $55 billion plan to modernize subways, buses and commuter rails is at risk because of revenue losses and increased borrowing caused by the coronavirus pandemic, according to a report issued Tuesday.

title: Simon & Schuster Says Pence Book to Proceed, Despite Employee Petitions
summary: 'We come to work each day to publish, not cancel,' CEO Jonathan Karp says in letter to staffers. Simon & Schuster Chief Executive Jonathan Karp said Tuesday the publisher would proceed with a book by former Vice President Mike Pence despite objections from some of its employees, saying he wants to preserve a culture that presents different perspectives.

title: Afghanistan: The U.S. Can Always Go Back
summary: Harsh but limited strikes can deter and punish terrorism. Nation building is an expensive diversion.. The U.S. is finally getting out of Afghanistan. While most Americans have long supported an exit, advocates of a continued U.S. military presence warn of the Afghan government's collapse, the subjugation of women and the re-establishment of a terrorist haven.

title: Tax Hikes Will Stifle the Recovery
summary: Biden's proposal would make American companies less competitive overseas, resulting in lost U.S. jobs.. The Biden administration and congressional Democrats' $2.7 trillion "infrastructure plan" is deeply concerning. Republicans and Democrats agree on investing in America's infrastructure-the roads, bridges, electrical grids, railroads and broadband networks we all use. The last infrastructure bill passed by Congress, 2015's Fixing America's Surface Transportation Act, cost about $300 billion and passed 359-65 in the House and 83-16 in the Senate. The Biden plan broadens the definition of infrastructure to include more than $2 trillion in funding for things like the National Science Foundation, long-term care, corporate child care, and electric-car companies. Some are worthy causes, but they don't belong in an infrastructure bill.

title: Meatpacker JBS USA Hires New Chief Legal Officer
summary: The appointment of Kevin Arquit, a former U.S. antitrust enforcer, comes as the U.S. meat industry faces antitrust scrutiny. summary: More business leaders are speaking out on political issues in response to pressure from younger consumers and employees. Here are three ways young Americans are helping to shape the new wave of political activism from business leaders.

summary: Chat startup to stay independent as it resumes interest in a potential initial public offering. Tribune Publishing Co. has set a May 21 deadline for shareholders to vote on a takeover proposal by hedge fund Alden Global Capital LLC, narrowing the window for hotel magnate Stewart Bainum Jr. to firm up financing for his competing bid.

title: TikTok Adds Automated Captions, Making Platform More Open to Deaf People
summary: Advocates welcome the new feature, the latest move among social media companies to make their platforms more accessible to all. TikTok is introducing automated captions, a feature that will add subtitles to posts in its popular video-sharing app without requiring users to enter the text themselves.

title: SNC-Lavalin Says World Bank Lifts Sanctions Imposed in 2013
summary: The sanctions stemmed from allegations the Canadian engineering company bribed officials in Bangladesh. SNC-Lavalin Group Inc. said Tuesday the World Bank Group has granted an early lifting of all sanctions imposed in 2013 against the Canadian engineering company.

title: Oscars 2021: An Academy Award Ceremony Like No Other
summary: The stars gather for another chorus of 'Hooray for Hollywood,' at a time when it feels like 'High Noon' for the industry. Over the course of the pandemic the movies-theatrical films, that is-have suffered one loss after another. They lost the use of their showplaces, those ornate palaces, labyrinthine multiplexes and financially precarious independent theaters that have only now begun to reopen their doors and fire up their popcorn poppers. They lost their exclusivity when supposedly stellar attractions started streaming on home screens at the same time they were playing in whatever few theaters were still operating. They lost-at least for the time being-any claim they might have retained on their special place in the expanding universe of entertainment. And earlier this month came news of a stunning new loss-the apparently permanent closure, due to implacable pandemic economics, of the ArcLight chain of attractive, festive multiplexes, and of Hollywood's Cinerama Dome, arguably the most enjoyable place in the country to see a feature film.

title: How to Navigate Changing Etiquette as Covid Rules Shift
summary: Nobody knows how to interact with each other as vaccines change our social expectations. Here's how to handle it.. As more people get vaccinated, the ways we interact with each other are starting to change. Some people are comfortable forgoing Covid precautions, but others aren't-leading to some awkward social situations. Here's some advice on how to navigate these tricky times.

title: Minneapolis Braces for Derek Chauvin Verdict and Potential Unrest
summary: Destruction sparked by George Floyd's death last summer leaves residents along Nicollet Avenue preparing for the worst. MINNEAPOLIS-Julia Hinton walked along downtown's Nicollet Mall on Monday morning, watching as a man installed plywood over the doors and windows of 801 Chophouse on 8th Street and Nicollet Avenue. Armed troops and military vehicles stood posted near the Saks Off Fifth store a few blocks down on 6th, and several more lined the way to the already-boarded-up Target on 9th.

title: New Test Scores Show Students Rebounding After Pandemic-Related Learning Loss
summary: Tests show math progress since the fall, but students of color fell further behind. Many students are starting to rebound from academic setbacks more than a year after coronavirus pandemic restrictions upended education nationwide, according to a report released Tuesday on new testing data.

summary: Beijing plans to appoint Qin Gang, who has accompanied Xi on overseas trips, and Washington is expected to name R. Nicholas Burns, a veteran diplomat. summary: The additional visas will become available ahead of the summer season. The Biden administration will make an additional 22,000 seasonal guest-worker visas available this year ahead of the busy summer season, the Department of Homeland Security said Tuesday.

summary: Difference between the yields on Treasurys and German bunds has tightened as expectations about the relative pace of economic recovery shifted. title: Replying to Jeffrey Sonnenfeld on Woke CEOs
summary: In a large U.S. corporation, it is anything but courageous to recite the progressive party line or criticize a conservative position.. Jeffrey Sonnenfeld's "CEOs Lead America's New Great Awakening" (op-ed, April 16) purports to tell a heroic tale of the Yale dean's corralling business leaders to stand against the forces of darkness. (After all, the Georgia voting bill was "drafted in the dark of night.") But here is the sum total of information Mr. Sonnenfeld provides about the bill: "Among the law's antidemocratic features, it authorizes partisan legislators to dismiss the authority of elected county voting officials and override the elected secretary of state to decide, at will and after an election, whose ballots count."

title: Dealers Are Selling Cars So Fast They Don't Need to Borrow
summary: Snarled supply chain for new cars is slowing banks' loans to dealers, but surging used-car prices are a driving force for auto lenders. Here's another way to play the global chip shortage: Auto lenders.

title: Numbers Don't Add Up for the Vaccine Pause
summary: Many more lives are at risk than 6 in 6.8 million.. Your editorial "The J&J Covid Vaccine Pause" (April 14) doesn't make the necessary inferences. Six people in 6.8 million vaccinated have had cerebral venous sinus thrombosis (CVST). The "natural" annual incidence of these brain blood clots ranges from two to 16 per million. Using these figures, we would expect between 13 and 109 clots annually in 6.8 million people. Since the vaccine has been available for around six weeks, however, we'd expect between two and 13 clots over this period. Thus, the rate of clots in the vaccinated is similar to the "natural" rate. A U.K. study also shows that a Covid patient's risk of CVST is 100 times greater than normal and eight-to-10 times that of a vaccinated person. The CDC and FDA may be overreacting.

title: 'Mom Cardigan' Does Not Do This Garment Justice.
summary: The 'mom' reference and instructions on how to avoid a 'mumsy look' are pejorative.. "Clothing That Dates You" (Off Duty, April 10) calls draping Eileen Fisher cardigans "mom cardigans" and notes they are designed for a "widening behind." Comfortable yet refined, these flowing garments are empowering. They warm us on cold planes and in offices and transition from plane to corporate board meeting (often several times a week). Many also have pockets that allow us to carry our phones, pens and notes hands-free. These are all important and have nothing to do with covering my behind, which doesn't need covering.

title: RBG's Retirement Decision: A 'What If' for the Ages
summary: The coming legislation to pack the Supreme Court should be called the Ruth Bader Ginsburg Act.. Regarding Philip Hamburger's op-ed "Court Packing Is a Dangerous Game" (April 16): The coming legislation to pack the Supreme Court should be called the Ruth Bader Ginsburg Act. Justice Ginsburg rejected advice to retire when Barack Obama could appoint her successor. The result, when she died, was a Supreme Court with an additional Trump nominee, a liberal bloc reduced from four to three, and now, prompted by the disparity, the move to pack the court. It's all part of the Ginsburg legacy.

title: China's Xi Lays Out Vision for a World Without a Single Dominant Power

title: The Derek Chauvin Trial Is With the Jury. What's Next?
summary: Jurors have begun deliberating over the charges facing the former police officer accused of killing George Floyd. A Minnesota jury began its deliberations Monday over whether former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin is guilty of murder in the death of George Floyd, a Black man whose fatal arrest last year was captured on video and set off a wave of protests calling for racial justice and changes to policing practices. The jury deliberated until 8 p.m. Monday, and started again at 8 a.m. Tuesday morning.

summary: Resume Subscription. For those who enjoy a retail real-estate mystery, here's one that puzzled me recently. Then Covid-19 hit. And what happened? Its vacancy rate actually dropped, to 6.4%.

title: A Major Record-Setting Ceramic Artist Returns to the U.S.
summary: For her first show in the U.S. in over 30 years, Kenyan-born ceramic artist Magdalene Odundo, 70, shows supple earthenware vessels that are among the most coveted in the world. Magdalene Odundo is a cricket fan, and she keeps a newspaper clipping of the South African bowler Paul Adams pinned to a wall of her studio. In it, Adams-neck craning, arms windmilling, hurtling forward on one outstretched leg as he unloads the ball-almost defies the rules of nature. Odundo calls the movement "balletic." Visitors to her studio, in Surrey, England, have said similar things about her pots. Asked where her inspiration comes from, she answers, "Everywhere. All the time."

title: The Hamptons Take Wait-and-See Approach on Marijuana
summary: Despite New York state's move to legalize cannabis, towns on Long Island's eastern end consider charting their own course. Communities throughout the eastern end of New York's Long Island are grappling over whether to opt out of a new state law that legalized the sale of recreational marijuana for adults beginning next year.

title: Blackstone Bets on India E-Commerce With Warehouse Deal
summary: Investment firm intends to acquire and develop a logistics portfolio that could eventually cover 21.5 million square feet. Blackstone Group Inc., already the largest owner of office buildings in India, is about to become one of that country's biggest owners of warehouses, too.

title: Landlords Find Relying on One Office Tenant Can Backfire
summary: Leasing an entire building to one company is often an efficient way to collect steady rent checks, but some of these tenants are deciding not to renew. With the U.S. office market in its worst crisis in a decade, some landlords are discovering the risks of putting all their tenant eggs in one basket.

title: This New York Hotel Quarantined the Sick. Now the Owners Regret It.
summary: Resume Subscription. ROCHESTER, N.Y.-When the pandemic erupted last spring, the husband-and-wife owners of an upstate New York hotel felt compelled to offer the 43-room property to Monroe County authorities for use as a quarantine facility.

title: The Covid-19 Risk to Markets Isn't All Over
summary: India's worsening outbreak is taking the sheen off its impressive equity-market performance. The surge in Covid-19 infections in India threatens to overwhelm the country's healthcare system, prompting a lockdown in New Delhi, which may be followed elsewhere. That's now being reflected in financial markets: Indian equities are hurting again.

title: Travelers Sees Pre-Tax Catastrophe Losses More Than Double
summary: The property-casualty insurer reports increased profit and revenue in latest quarter. Travelers Cos.' pretax catastrophe losses more than doubled from a year ago for the company's first quarter, due in part to winter storms.

title: Satellite Images Show Russia's Expanding Ukraine Buildup
summary: Resume Subscription. Russia has moved warplanes to Crimea and bases near Ukraine to an extent greater than has previously been disclosed, adding to its capability for political intimidation or military intervention, according to commercial satellite photos of areas being used for the military buildup.

title: Toshiba Rebuffs CVC Takeover Offer
summary: Japanese industrial conglomerate says it prefers to stay a public company. Toshiba Corp. rebuffed a takeover proposal from private-equity firm CVC Capital Partners , saying the proposal didn't have enough detail to be considered and Toshiba preferred to remain a public company.

title: More Hispanic Americans Are Buying Homes
summary: Number of Hispanic homeowners rose by more than 700,000 to nearly 9 million in 2020, the biggest one-year increase in two decades. Hispanic homeownership grew at a record pace last year, fueled by younger buyers who have helped make this demographic a growing force in the red-hot U.S. housing market.

title: The One-Way Bet on Carbon Credits Has Limits
summary: European emission allowances, one of this year's hottest commodities, have room to rise further-as long as investors don't all pile in at once. European carbon credits are as close as investors can come to a sure thing. Ironically, the chief thing that might trip them up is too much excitement too soon.

title: Many Russians Side With Putin Over Navalny Standoff
summary: Resume Subscription. KALININGRAD, Russia-Thousands of demonstrators are expected to take to the streets in many Russian cities Wednesday in support of Alexei Navalny, the jailed opposition leader who has galvanized popular discontent with the long rule of President Vladimir Putin.

title: New Carbon Market Pays Southern Pine-Growers Not to Cut
summary: Resume Subscription. Here is a new way for Southern pine growers to get paid for their timber: Leave it standing.

title: Compliance Helps Ensure Covid-Relief Pledges Are Met, Sallie Mae's Compliance Chief Says
summary: Student lender Sallie Mae in January hired Kerri Palmer, a former risk manager for Capital One Financial Corp., to serve as its new chief risk and compliance officer. Student lender Sallie Mae says it has taken steps to offer relief to borrowers whose education may have been disrupted by the pandemic or to loan recipients who may have lost their jobs or had their hours cut back.

title: A Covid-19 Lesson From Countries With Rapid Vaccine Rollouts
summary: Israel, the U.K. and Chile have different experiences after quickly delivering inoculations. Rapid Covid-19 vaccination rollouts in Israel, the U.K. and Chile hold an important lesson for the U.S. as it navigates back to normalcy: Risks remain, even after inoculating a significant share of your population.

title: Tax Bills May Go Up for Big Companies. It Will Be Hard to Tell How Much.
summary: Public companies aren't required to disclose the amount of taxes they pay in each of the states or countries where they operate. U.S. companies might have to pay more in taxes to fund President Biden's $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan. How much they owe and to whom will likely remain a mystery.

title: Behind the Mysterious Demise of a $1.7 Billion Mutual Fund
summary: Resume Subscription. A U.S. mutual fund that suffered nearly $500 million of losses appears to have misvalued its large derivatives portfolio, according to an analysis of the fund's disclosures by The Wall Street Journal, academics and traders.

title: Covid-19 Slashed Emissions. Now They're Climbing Again.
summary: The International Energy Agency expects a 4.8% rise this year, the biggest annual gain since 2010. Soaring carbon emissions this year are on track to reverse a big chunk of last year's sharp reduction, which some climate researchers had hoped might be an environmental silver lining of the pandemic.

title: Tesla Faces New China Test After Woman's Auto-Show Protest Goes Viral
summary: Demonstrator draws wide sympathy after climbing atop Tesla Model 3 sedan and shouting allegations about faulty brakes, and videos show her being dragged away. SHANGHAI-A single protester with a disputed claim about the safety of Tesla Inc. electric vehicles has hit a nerve in China, sending complaints about the company ricocheting across the Chinese internet and refocusing attention on alleged quality issues in a critical market for Tesla.

title: New York's Selective Public Schools Aren't Only for the Wealthy
summary: More than 60% of the students at Brooklyn Tech High School and nearly half the students at Stuyvesant High School live in poverty.. Eva Moskowitz makes an excellent point that New York City students suffer from a shortage of good schools ("Great Schools Are the Solution to Educational 'Segregation,' " Cross Country, April 12). But we shouldn't make the mistake of viewing the city's selective schools as disproportionately composed of the children of affluent white families.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Walter Mondale, Vice President to Carter, Dies at 93
summary: Democratic politician, statesman and Minnesota native raised the status of the vice presidency. Former Vice President Walter Mondale, a civil rights champion who lost a 1984 White House bid in one of the largest Electoral College landslides in U.S. history, died Monday evening at his home in Minneapolis. He was 93.

title: China's Meituan Amasses $10 Billion War Chest for Drones and Driverless Cars
summary: Company also unveils new generation of self-driving delivery cars it says are smarter, safer than previous versions. China's Meituan is raising nearly $10 billion from investors, hoping it will be able to gain an edge on its e-commerce rivals by spending heavily on technology allowing it to deliver goods using drones and self-driving cars.

title: China's Digital Yuan Poses No Threat to the Dollar's Dominance
summary: New payment methods won't transform a currency that foreigners don't want to hold into one that they do. Excitable commentators who say China's digital yuan is a threat to the dollar should take the word of Chinese central bank deputy governor Li Bo, who said on Sunday that the country's digital yuan isn't an effort to displace the greenback.

title: Maxine Roils the Chauvin Waters
summary: The trial judge says her comments could lead to a successful appeal.. Well, this certainly is a mess, and let's hope it doesn't turn tragic. Maxine Waters, the House Financial Services Committee chair, might have poisoned the Derek Chauvin trial now reaching its conclusion in Minneapolis.

title: Photos: Remembering Walter Mondale
summary: The Minnesota politician who served as a senator, vice president and U.S. ambassador shaped civil rights policy and brokered international agreements. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Lithium Miners Ink $3 Billion Merger as Demand for Electric Vehicles Booms
summary: Deal would create one of world's biggest lithium producers as commodity's prices climb on growing EV sales. SYDNEY- Orocobre Ltd. agreed to buy rival Australian miner Galaxy Resources Ltd. in an all-stock deal that would create a $3 billion miner and one of the world's biggest producers of lithium, a commodity used in batteries for electric vehicles and other high-tech products.

title: Elon Musk Weighs In on Fatal Tesla Crash as Safety Officials Investigate
summary: Tesla CEO says data recovered so far shows the car's Autopilot system wasn't enabled. U.S. safety officials are investigating a fatal weekend crash involving a Tesla Inc. vehicle, adding to a series of probes into incidents involving the electric-vehicle maker.
